A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Orbit to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an Orbit explicitly involves the action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x$ in $X$ is defined as the set of all elements obtained by applying each element of the group $G$ to $x$. This definition inherently requires the concept of a group because it uses the group elements to define the orbit. Without understanding what a group is, and without a group to provide the elements for the action, the concept of an orbit cannot be established or understood. Therefore, the concept of a group is essential and foundational for defining the concept of an orbit.
